message_1: What is the phase difference between two light waves of equal intensity and frequency, traveling in opposite directions, that interfere destructively? Assume the speed of light in vacuum is 299,792,458 m/s.
message_2:
In order to interfere destructively, the two light waves must be out of phase by half a wavelength (180 degrees or π radians). This is because the crest of one wave will coincide with the trough of the other wave, resulting in a net amplitude of zero at the point of interference.

So, the phase difference between the two light waves for destructive interference is 180 degrees or π radians.
